awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Biological Adaptations to Stress - Molecular, Cellular, Ecological
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award to Pepperdine University, located in Malibu, CA, will support the training of 8 students for 11 weeks during the summers of 2020-2022. Over three years of the award, the program will train a total of 24 students, recruited primarily from schools with limited research opportunities and from underrepresented populations. The program focuses on biological adaptations to stress, and includes projects in cell biology, plant biology, mathematical modeling of biological systems, ecology, and microbiology. Through direct mentoring by faculty, students develop their own independent project questions emerging from a review of the current research literature. Students will engage in authentic and relevant research, with a goal to contribute scholarly findings to the research literature. All REU students will have access to state-of-the-art research infrastructure on the Pepperdine campus. Program success will be assessed using a common web-based assessment tool used by all REU programs (SALG URSSA), as well as specific tools developed within the Pepperdine program. Upon completion of the program, many students will present their research findings at local and national conferences. Students will be tracked after the program in order to determine their career paths.  

The Pepperdine REU program focuses on the biological adaptation to stress. Projects vary by discipline, but include ecological/genetic studies in the Santa Monica Mountains and Pacific Ocean adjacent to the Pepperdine campus, cellular and biochemical studies of the consequences of environmental toxins, mathematical modeling of biological systems, and the impact of environmental stress upon soil microbial diversity. The program specific aims are to: 1) enhance the maturation of undergraduate students as young scientists; 2) engage students in full-time, authentic biological research and the effective communication of research findings; 3) introduce students to bioinformatics and mathematical modeling; 4) train students to engage non-scientists and the public through service and clear communication; and 5) provide research opportunities for students from underrepresented groups and from schools that lack research opportunities. For more information about the program, students can visit the website (https://seaver.pepperdine.edu/surb/) where they can apply online.  In addition, students can contact the PI (Dr. Jay Brewster at jay.brewster@pepperdine.edu).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Pepperdine Summer Undergraduate Research in Biology (SURB) program is an NSF-funded program that offers summer research fellowships to undergraduate students. The program supports 8 students each summer, providing each student a full-time, 11-week research experience. Students are closely mentored by Pepperdine faculty and are provided a generous student stipend, free housing on campus at Pepperdine, and support for travel. The central goal of the SURB program is to provide undergraduate students a genuine research experience, making real scientific progress in close partnership with faculty mentors, and broadening their consideration of careers in biological research, biotechnology, environmental science, and education. Research students engage the theme of stress adaptation of biological systems. Projects within the program include ecology, cellular and molecular biology, plant physiology, marine biology, genomics, bioinformatics, and mathematical modeling of biological systems. Students are welcomed into the scientific community and enjoy opportunities for social engagement, outreach, and the hosting of guest scientists from around the world.

The key objectives of the program are to:
1) enhance the maturation of undergraduate students as young scientists via direct faculty mentoring within the context of an active research laboratory;
2) engage students in full-time, authentic biological research by experimentally testing student-generated hypotheses, interpreting results, and effectively communicating research findings in oral and written format;
3) introduce students to the benefits of interdisciplinary collaboration and research skills in bioinformatics and mathematical modeling;
4) train students to engage non-scientists and the public through service and clear communication; and
5) provide research opportunities for students from underrepresented groups and from schools that lack research opportunities.

The SURB program has a 35-year history of supporting undergraduates in pursuing biological research. Students who have participated in the SURB program over the past three years on this current grant have been successful in addressing important publishable questions in biology, have engaged the broader scientific community effectively, and have been a diverse group of talented students from across the United States. Since 2021, this grant has funded research by 27 undergraduates and one post-baccalaureate student.  SURB students have authored 6 undergraduate honors theses and 7 research articles in respected, peer-reviewed scientific journals since 2021. The publication of research results generated during the SURB program is challenging due to the brevity of the program and the rigor required of such scholarly communications. These publications attest to the quality of the research projects being performed, the quality of the students participating in the program, and the extended connection between SURB students and their faculty mentor during the process of publishing in a peer-reviewed journal. In addition, SURB students funded by this grant have given 40 conference presentations to communicate their research findings to the scientific community. Examples include the Ecological Society of America, the American Association for Cancer Research, and the Joint Mathematics Meetings, which offer important opportunities for undergraduate students to network and to prepare for graduate school application.

Of the students funded by this grant, 86% have subsequently entered or plan to enter into graduate-level training or careers in the research biosciences. The SURB alumni are succeeding in gaining access to graduate programs and will become important members of the U.S. STEM professionals. When requesting funds for this grant, we set a goal of enriching the SURB program with a diverse collection of students. Of the students funded with this grant, 62% were from groups that are underrepresented in science, 83% have come from institutions that lack a Ph.D. in STEM disciplines, and 19% were first-year college students. Recently funded SURB students have come from 14 different colleges and universities, distributed among 7 states.

Faculty mentors and administrative staff make great effort to keep in contact with SURB alumni to offer sustained support and keep abreast of their career developments. We regularly maintain a database of durable contact information and career outcomes. Alumni also return as continuing researchers, give scholarly seminars, lead timely discussions about applying for awards and grants, and serve as keynote speakers who inspire current SURB students.

Over its long history, the SURB program has continued to grow and evolve, integrating new research areas and program components to engage students in cutting-edge research. In the last three years, we expanded interdisciplinary and quantitative biological training opportunities and strengthened training in scientific writing and peer review. We fostered sustained engagement with alumni and created additional research opportunities for students affected by pandemic shutdowns.  We also inaugurated new community outreach partnerships to continue to inspire scientific curiosity in the next generation of students.
